title: Chiara Battisti is researcher of English Literature at the Department of Foreign Literatures of the University of Verona. Her research interests include literature and the visual arts, with a particular focus on literature and cinema, literature and science, law and literature, food and literature, gender studies and fashion studies. She is a member of the European Society for the Study of English (ESSE), of AIA (Associazione Italiana di Anglistica) and of AIDEL (Associazione Italiana Diritto e Letteratura). Among her most recent publications are “Mental Illness and Human Rights in Patrick McGrath’s Asylum
Silence, Power and Suicide in Michael Cunningham’s The Hours
Western and Post-Western Mythologies of Law
True Blood: Multicultural Vampires in Contemporary Society

Cosmos, a journal of comparative literature (Torino). She is a member of Academia Europaea. She is in the scientific board of the series “Law and Humanities

title: Sidia Fiorato is Researcher of English Literature at the University of Verona. Her fields of research include detective fiction and the legal thriller, law, literature and culture, literature and the Performing Arts, Shakespeare Studies, the Fairy Tale. Among her publications are Il Gioco con l’ombra. Ambiguità e metanarrazioni nella narrativa di Peter Ackroyd
The Relationship Between Literature and Science in John Banville’s Scientific Tetralogy
essays on the contemporary novel, Shakespearian adaptations, Victorian Literature

note: she co-founded the European Network for Law and Literature (www.eurnll.org). She is the 2013 recipient of the J.B. White Award (bestowed by the Association for the Study of Law, Culture and Humanities). She also serves as a justice in the criminal law section of the Appellate Court of The Hague.
title: Jeanne Gaakeer holds degrees in English literature, Dutch law and philosophy. The focus of her research is on interdisciplinary movements in legal theory (specifically Law and Literature and Law and the Humanities) and their relevance to legal practice. She is endowed professor of legal theory at Erasmus School of Law, Rotterdam, the Netherlands

container-title: Terrorism, Media, and the Ethics of Fiction: Transatlantic Perspectives on Don DeLillo
note: as well as articles on cognitive poetics, literature and visual art, media history, cultural studies, and law and literature. Since 2006 he has been a member of the board of the German Association for American Studies
title: Peter Schneck is Professor and Chair of American Studies at Osnabrück University, director of the Osnabrück Summer Institute on the Cultural Study of the Law (OSI) and co-director of the research cluster “Cognition and Poetics.” He has been a fellow at the National Museum of American Art, Smithsonian Institution (Washington D.C.) and a visiting scholar at the University of California at Irvine, Nottingham University and the University of Torino, Italy. Most recent publications include Rhetoric and Evidence: Legal Conflict and Literary Representation in American Culture
